fields.description:
I was able to reproduce the problem. Per customer,
bq. If we modify the cloned plan's Fisheye URL field from "http://${bamboo.fisheyeServer}" to a hardcoded "http://spdfisheye.fnis.com" (bamboo.fisheyeServer = spdfisheye.fnis.com) we are able to save from the Source Repository page. 
However, It doesn't even work for new created (not cloned) plans.
fields.summary: Unable to use global variables in the Web Repository field

fields.description:
After updating bamboo from 3.2.3 to 3.3.2 CVS updates always pull the whole CVS repository root instead of the specified module.

The CVS update command sent by bamboo 3.2.3 looked like this:
Running CVS command: 'update -d -P -kb -D 2011-10-28 16:49:00 +0200 '
... in: 'Z:/bamboo/bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir/ACC-DEF-JOB1/siemens/03098 - Siemens ACC'
... CVSROOT: ':pserver:bamboo@carl:/var/cvs'

While the update command (same plan and same job) sent by bamboo 3.3.2 is:
Running CVS command: 'update -d -P -kb -D 2011-11-07 09:19:52 +0100 '
... in: 'Z:/bamboo/bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir/ACC-DEF-JOB1'
... CVSROOT: ':pserver:bamboo@carl:/var/cvs'

Note the missing module name in the path.

Forcing clean builds is our current workaround which increases build time significantly.
fields.summary: wrong path in CVS update command

Use case: Our release plan builds a Mercurial tag, the tag needs to be specified when running the plan. The build will fail if they don't enter a tag but having bamboo automatically prompt for this would feel very nice.

Currently, only svnkit-cli-1.2.1.5297.jar is available at /scripts/lib. However, svnkit-1.2.1.5297.jar is also necessary.

Since the svnkit lib is missing, the following exception is reported when running jsvn:

fields.description:
I tried bumping UPM to support Bamboo 3.3 from 3.1, and we got some failing tests with regards to the tests of the @RequiresRestart. Everything worked in Bamboo 3.1, but there's something wrong in Bamboo 3.3.

Note that this only happens when I'm installing a new plugin with a module that requires restart. But it works as expected when "upgrading" a plugin (i.e., @RequiresRestart is honored)
fields.summary: Bamboo 3.3 does not respect @RequiresRestart

fields.description:
When a sourcecode task is done in the 1st stage, and not in a later stage the bamboo.repository.revision.number is not set for the jobs in the later stage. 

This is impractical as the later jobs might need this variable.

Could work around it if it was possible to set the bamboo.repository.revision.number into a plan variable in the first stage.
fields.summary: If source code task is not in a job then bamboo.repository.revision.number is not set (even if its available in previous jobs)

fields.description:
This error happens because the column COMMIT_REVISION in the table USER_COMMIT is set to TEXT, 

{code}
2011-10-24 12:06:05,071 ERROR [main] [SchemaUpdate] Unsuccessful: create index commit_rev_idx on USER_COMMIT (COMMIT_REVISION)
2011-10-24 12:06:05,071 ERROR [main] [SchemaUpdate] BLOB/TEXT column 'COMMIT_REVISION' used in key specification without a key length
{code}

There is a limitation on indexing [TEXT type fields|http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1827063/mysql-error-key-specification-without-a-key-length]. As [this post|http://forums.mysql.com/read.php?98,37000,37052] states, we can have VARCHAR type with maximum 65,532 bytes after MySQL 5.0.3.  

We should change the column type from TEXT to VARCHAR.
fields.summary: Indexing problem in table USER_COMMIT because of column COMMIT_REVISION text type

fields.summary: Improvements to EBS mounting

fields.description:
On JBAC we only allow 1 or sometimes 2 concurrent builds.  If one of these fails for some reason and we want to rerun the failed builds.  We have to manage to hit the UI at that magic moment between one build finishing and the next starting.  As you can imagine this is quite difficult and requires someone to sit watching the UI for ages.

It would be good if you could "queue a build up for later" so that once the current build finishes the next build will be the rerun rather than a fresh change detection.

I imagine this is also a problem for continuing a manual stage. Or any other manual kicking off of a build.
fields.summary: Problems with Rerun Failed Jobs (and continuing manual stages) and Concurrent Build Limitations

fields.description:
If a P4 Checkout Task is used, Bamboo will consider the Working Dir to be the P4 Client Workspace.

However, if the Checkout Task is removed and the P4 repo is used to trigger the build based on change detection, the Working Dir will be set back to the <bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/ folder.

Would be good to give the option to allow the P4 Workspace to continue to be the working Dir.

If the Checkout Task is not being used, the Plan will still have to checkout the code somehow. And the P4 Client Workspace will still the the location for the code.
fields.summary: Allow Perforce to continue using the Workspace as Working Directory when the Checkout Task is removed

fields.description:
Ignore criteria:
 - commit messages with a certain regex (predefined regexex for Maven commits)
 - commits done by a user on a configurable list
 - commits matching repository / branch (e.g. to ignore certain externals)
 - Whatever user wants via a plugin point for that.
This should probably be available per repository, plan, project and globally.
fields.summary: Make it possible for build trigger mechanism to ignore certain commits

fields.description:
On Tardigrade: [http://tardigrade.sydney.atlassian.com:8085/bamboo/browse/ZZPSTEFANIAK-GITHTTPTEST/config]

{noformat}
Source repository: 
<twixie> Git git://github.com/doctrine/doctrine2.git
+---
| Source Control = Git 
| Repository URL = http://github.com/atlassian/org.eclipse.jgit-atlassian.git 
| Branch         = shallow
{noformat}

I've just changed that repository configuration (from org.eclipse.jgit-atlassian.git to doctrine2.git, and removed branch) and I expected that in the view configuration page I'll see new RepositoryURL and new branch. Instead I see configuration from before my changes. What is weird is that the repository description (right of first "Git") is showing proper repositoryUrl.

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed an OS command injection vulnerability in the third-party Perforce library used by Bamboo.

* An attacker can take advantage of the vulnerability to execute arbitrary commands on a Bamboo server.

This issue is reported in our security advisory on this page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/lwH6Dw

Patch is available, see the attached file.

fields.description:
This brings about billions of transitive dependencies (run mvn dependency:tree in bamboo-acceptance-test to see it yourself), which is asking for trouble. Recent story: unable to run Webdriver via IDEA because there is dozens of imports of httpclient 3.0.x where WebDriver needs 4.1.x. Approach taken in JIRA (and worth replicating IMO):
- remove dependencies on API/core (any utils - extract into common module that has limited controllable number of deps, or just copy from core as necessary)
- remove dependency on webapp by having a separate module to run the tests that live in bamboo-acceptance-test
fields.summary: Bamboo acceptance tests should not depend on any bamboo production code

fields.description:
Bamboo currently provides 5 basic permissions that can be applied on a per-plan basis:
* View
* Edit
* build
* Clone
* Admin

We have the need for a sixth:
* Pass Manual Stages

*And Ideally this would be a per-stage permission*


We use manual stages for deployment and verification steps.  However our organization enforces strict segregation of duties, so a Developer may *never* deploy to non-dev environments.  That is why we would like to add our deployment team's group to specific manual stages.


This would give us the future flow of:
# Stage 1 (build, test and tag)
## Developer releases current version from Jira
## Release invokes a build in Bamboo
### Checkout latest
### Run unit and acceptance tests
### Report on code coverage, findbugs, pmd
### Tag JIra version (1.2.2-SNAPSHOT) in VCS
# Stage 2 - Manual (deploy to Dev)
## Execute deployment scripts (Developers or Deployers only)
# Stage 3 - Manual (deploy to Test or Performance)
## Execute deployment scripts (Deployers only)
fields.summary: Create distinct permission for Manual Stages in a build pipeline.

fields.description:
From what I udnerstand due to Subversion's backwards compatability, if Subversion 1.7 is running on the server, Bamboo will work with no problems.

However, it will act as a Subversion 1.6 client.

To support 1.7 subversion workspace, we most likely will have to upgrade SVNKit to do this.

fields.description:
Make it possible to publish artifacts out-and-beyond the bamboo environment, e.g. to a staging server.

Caveat: If you're using remote build agents, this may be impossible for them to perform, and would quickly get quite complex to implement rules to achieve and filter suitable agents.

I'm thinking one of two options:

 a/ Additional artifact definition attributes specifying "Publish" and a publish-to destination; after the build-agent completes its task, it pumps the artifact to the server and the server does the copy;
 b/ A publish plugin

TBH, this seems like such a standard component of build cycles ... that I can't see why (a) wouldn't be the more appealing option.

{code:xml}
<configuration>
  <inheritRepository>false</inheritRepository>
  <selectedWebRepositoryViewer>bamboo.webrepositoryviewer.provided:noRepositoryViewer</selectedWebRepositoryViewer>
  <repository>
    <change>
      <schedule>
        <cronExpression>0 0 0 ? * MON</cronExpression>
      </schedule>
    </change>
  </repository>
  <selectedBuildStrategy>schedule</selectedBuildStrategy>
  <custom>
    <auto>
      <label/>
      <regex/>
    </auto>
    <ncover>
      <path/>

    <clover>
      <path/>
      <license/>
      <useLocalLicenseKey>true</useLocalLicenseKey>

</configuration>

fields.description:
Since working on the JIRA team i have discovered that 2 commits is really not enough. 

There are two pieces of information i need (in order of importance)
# Is this my build
# which of my commits is in the build

Possible Solutions
* Show all commits, or a larger cut (maybe 5)
* Show a summary and the existing 2 commits.  E.g. Commits by Brydie, James, Mark and Bob (Solves objective 1 but not objective 2)
* Show a summary and expandable details section of all commits (You could show maybe the Name, Commit number and as much text from the commit message as fits on one line?)
* Have some other indicator on the page saying that its contains the currently viewing user's commit. (Solves objective 1 but not objective 2)
* Order my commits first on the summary page rather than by time...
fields.summary: Show more than 2 commits on the build result summary page OR at least a summary of all

b) on pages where you can't see changes you could use the tooltip if it exists (I find myself trying to do this a lot then being disapointed when I cant)

fields.description:
In JIRA 4.4.2, the format for drop-down list storage changed. This means that the some of the in-product "request support" links throw warnings when attempting to create an issue.  The link for Bamboo is not currently broken, but this is a brittle way to get customers to create issues.  A single change to the project structure or custom fields will result in errors. Also, no relevant customer data will be included when the issue is created, which often results in delays for the customer.

The "Request Support" link in the footer should be replaced with a link to the "Support Request" module in the Support Tools Plugin.  That feature is designed to send a formatted email that is parsed and turned into an issue by a custom mail handler that is kept up to date with both SAC's configuration and the version of JIRA we're running.
fields.summary: Need to update the "Request Support" link in the site footer.

fields.description: I can't seem to reliably navigate to the PlanSummaryPage properly. That required "indicator" is missing a lot.  If I go to the dashboard first then to the PlanSummaryPage it seems to be more reliable.
fields.summary: The PlanSummaryPage object indicator is flakey.

fields.description: Its an absolute pain when developing amps plugins because everytime bamboo starts up it doesn't have and jdk's or executables set up.  If it could click the updateDefaultsLocalCapability action after import, all this stuff would get pulled in from your local environment.
fields.summary: Bamboo AMPS setup should hit the updateDefaultsLocalCapability link after import
Plugin SDK to create a task plugin cannot start in Bamboo 3.3

fields.description:
We don't know why this occurs, but sometimes the LIST_POSITION in the CHAIN_STAGE table is set to -1
This prevents the Bamboo server from starting up 

There is an KB with a workaround:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Bamboo+Server+fails+to+Initialize+Plans+on+Server+Restart
fields.summary: Chain Stage list position gets corrupted
